title: Which country had the most casualties during World War I? - Quora

response.answer_text: The country that lost the most soldiers was Tsarist Russia (followed by France). The war in the East was brutal and the imperial regime in Russia had tremendous problems domestically, with tens of thousands of workers on the streets of Saint Petersburg and Moscow demanding the end of the monarchy. According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, Russia mobilized 12 million men, and 1.2 million were killed while 4.95 million men were wounded. Additionally, 2.5 million soldiers were either captured or went missing, bringing the total casualties for the war to 9.5 million soldiers.[1] Russia was an agrarian society with poorly-maintained infrastructure and a general lack of proper military equipment to arm and supply soldiers in the front. Soldiers often died due to logistical issues. With the Provisional Government taking power and then the October Revolution by the Bolshevik branch of the Worker’s Party later that same year, Russia was ill prepared, if at all, to the demands that modern warfare required. The high death toll can only be explained through military negligence, poor logistics and a general lack of enthusiasm in defending the vestiges of an absolute monarchy that was extremely unpopular. Footnotes[1] World War I - Killed, wounded, and missing

Russia or to be more precise. Had suffered the most, more than any other country in Europe or the far East. All in all approximately 1,700,000 Millions were parishes and terminated by the Wermacht. The trenches war, Starvation due to the cold winter. During the last Far kingdom. The war against Germany was ceased by Lenin after the Bolshevik revolution. Soldeirs that were taken as prisoners of war and taken to force labour and were killed by the Germans. PBS: The Great War World War One: Casualty and Death Tables One way to understand the violence and slaughter that occurred in the Great War is to examine the number of casualties and deaths. Exact figures are still in dispute, because of different definitions used for each category, the questionable accuracy of the recording system used and the loss or destruction of a number of official documents. The data in the tables below reflect numbers from several sources and are consistant with most experts' current estimates. Country. Total Mobilized Forces	Killed. Wounded Prisoners and Missing. Russia. They were pretty much spent by 1915, and the Brusilov Offensives spurred them closer and closer to Vienna and Budapest by 1917, but they lost huge amounts of men. This was partly because of piss poor leadership on the part of the military generals, and also the German victories capturing Russian forts around their borders. But mostly because every time a disaster happened, say, the Battle of Tannenberg and the Gorlitze-Tarnow offensive, the Russian leadership would say, “So what? It’s only men.” As a percentage of their population, Serbia. They were the first defenders of the war, and one of the smallest countries that were in for it the full way through. Deadliest battle per country: British: Battle of the Somme - 1916 (almost 30,000 dead on the first day) French: Battle of the Frontiers - 1914 (showing up in full Napoleonic custom, they were quickly chopped to peices by German gunners) Germany: Also the Somme Russia: Battle of Tannenberg - 1914 (complete Eradication of Russian 2nd Army) America - Meuse-Argonne Offensive - 1918 (also the deadliest battle in American history) Turkey - gallipolli Campaign

Ooo! That’s interesting. Now you and me might say the Somme. Or maybe Third Wipers. If not, I’d have guessed an Eastern Front battle (there was one - the Germans won). Nope. The answer is the Hundred Days Offensive - the one that won the war for the Allies in 1918. 2.2 million (!!!). Somme was 1.2 million. Passchendaele was just 0.6 - just a scratch lads! Other biggies: Great Retreat (Russia retreats from Poland in 1915 - pretty much losing the war) - 1.9 million; 1918 Spring Offensive (Germany fails to win) - 1.5 million. Brusilov (Russian stupidity in 1916 that cost the Tsar his crown) - 1.6 million. Well there you go. Learn summat new every day.

It depends on what you call a battlefield as some offensives were mounted along fronts of up to a hundred miles or more so as such each stretch of front line could be said to contain numerous battlefields. Basically though in the west the areas around Ypres, across the Somme river and around Verdun were some of the most fought over and the offensives there produced some of the highest casualty rates overall. In Italy there were also an insane 12 battles across and around the Isonzo River though I don’t know the total number of fatalities for all of them together. The front line in the east tended to be a lot more mobile though I know there was a lot of fighting in areas like East Prussia and Galicia.

SSSR by far and they were under-reporting - a number of 40 million people was mentioned. Second, Poland - all the camps were there. So, in reality - Yugoslavia - slightly more than 11 percent or so (prewar 11 million, losses 1.6 million), Germans and other occupiers shot less than 400.000, ustashas killed around 600.000, partisans shot at the end of the war some 100.000–150.000 and the rest died in the civil war, from diseases, malnutrition, starvation etc.

Probably the Somme, at about 1.2 million, which is particularly sad given that the attack was meant for the British to divert the Germans from Verdun, where the French had suffered near a million caasualties themselves. Interestingly, from War Losses (Germany) A table showing what “casualty” actual means.

In the period 1917–1919, 8–10 million Iranians died of starvation and diseases as a result of British blockade of that country. This took place in the occupied areas of Iran even though it had declared neutrality. The population of the country was only 18 million at the time. This is the highest level of casualties that can be attributed to World War I. Very few people know about this as “History is indeed written by the victors”!

The 100 days offensive in 1918 which ended the war had the most casualties. While the other infamous battles mentioned produced about half a million casualties for both sides, the 100 days offensive produced over 1 million casualties for both sides. The offensive may technically be multiple smaller battles, but I believe it counts, and 100 days was shorter than many of the other infamous battles.

It depends on how you define a battle, but by my definition it would be the Hundred Days Offensive. 1,855,369 total casualties. The battle began on the 8th of August and continued on into November. Hundred Days Offensive - Wikipedia 785,733 Germans casualties. 1,069,636 allied casualties.     And for what?

Battles in WW1 were not one or two day affairs when are referred to as “battles” are actually “offensives” which usually went on for 4 to 6 months The candidates would be Ypres - that small area covers three offensives and was fought over for 4 years The Menin Gate in Ypres commemorate 54,000 men who were never found there are approximately 60 Military Cemeteries in the Ypres Salient

Without any research I would have to say either the 11 month long Battle of Verdun that cost the French and Germans about a million casualties or the 5 month long Battle of the Somme that cost the British and Germans at least a million casualties. Im not aware of any other pitched confrontation with more casualties (although the 3rd Battle of Ypres comes close with perhaps 850,000 casualties.

The Battle of the Somme 1916, The Battle of Verdun 1916, The Battle of Passchendaele 1917, Second Battle of Ypres 1915( use of poison gas ), First Battle of the Marne 1914 and the Battle of Tannenberg 1914

in term of %, serbia suffered the most, with at least 22 % of the population who died ( yes you heard me right, who died ) then France with 15 % of france population as casualties ( killed/wounded/missing)
Which World War I had the most casualties? the one from 1914–8

In WWI Russia had the most casualties with 9,150,000. However, Germany suffered the most deaths with 1,773,700. Highest Casualties as % of Forces was Austria-Hungary with 7,020,000 total casualties which was 90.0% followed by Russia 76.3%. and then France 73.3%. Source: WWI Casualty and Death Tables The Great War . Resources . WWI Casualties and Deaths
The Somme for sure. Bloodiest day in British military history was in the early days where they had over 50,000 casualties in one day…. Let me repeat that… 50,000 casualties in ONE DAY….

Which World War I had the most casualties?- The original one. or did you intend to ask, “Which World War I battle had the most casualties?”?- I’m pretty sure a quick Google search will provide you the answer.

Although I do not have the source handy, recent science and studies put the casualties of the expanded French empire at being between seven to eight million. In addition, similar recent studies, (as within the last 20 years), estimated Russian casualties to be in the same range.
In terms of raw numbers, Russia. In terms of percentage of prewar population, Serbia. Russia lost the most, but also had a huge population. Serbia didn't have that many to lose to start with.
Germany had the most military dead with 2,040,000 Both Russia and Turkey had about 2,000,000 civilians dead In total, 8.5 to 10 million military dead and over 20 million wounded

Poland. Warsaw was almost totally destroyed, its population decimated by the Germans and the Russians. First, they divided Poland in 1939, both slaughtering all those who opposed them in their respective parts, Then the Germans came through in Operation Barbarosa slaughtering the pro red poles. In 1945, the Red Army came through, and slaughtered all the pro German Poles.
